userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center has title, copyright, and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them, and has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is divided into eight subseries that reflect the individual appointments--with the exception of Subseries 5, which consolidates Rockefeller's three government reorganization committee appointments--plus one additional subseries that contains declassified documents from two of his appointments. The nine subseries are:

Subseries 1: Coordinator of Inter-American AffairsSubseries 2: Assistant Secretary of State for American Republic AffairsSubseries 3: Inter-American Development Commission and CorporationSubseries 4: International Development Advisory BoardSubseries 5A: Special Committee on Government Organization (SCOGO)Subseries 5B: Reorganization Advisory Committee (RAC)Subseries 5C: President's Advisory Committee on Government Organization (PACGO)Subseries 6: Department of Health, Education, and Welfare (HEW)Subseries 7: Special Assistant to the President for Foreign AffairsSubseries 8: Presidential Mission to Latin AmericaSubseries 9: Declassified Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is made up of Nelson A. Rockefeller's personal copies of correspondence, reports, and other documents gathered during his service in the federal government in ten presidential appointments between 1940 and 1969. All manner of documents can be found in these files, from handwritten notes to printed reports. Marginal notes found in Rockefeller's handwriting are not uncommon. These records both duplicate and complement official government records held in the National Archives and in presidential libraries.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Following a 1939 tour of Latin America, Rockefeller sent a memorandum to President Franklin D. Roosevelt that expressed concern over Nazi influence in that region and recommended a program of U.S. cooperation and assistance to raise the standard of living in Latin America and to improve relations between the nations of the western hemisphere. President Roosevelt responded by appointing Rockefeller to head a new program that became the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs. Following the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941, the agency coordinated the strategic defense of the region in the fields of information, economics, health, sanitation, agriculture, transportation, and culture and actively worked to frustrate Axis propaganda campaigns and economic designs on Latin America.

This subseries includes 6 cubic feet of correspondence and 19 cubic feet of bound printed material such as reports, newsletters, circulars issued by the various divisions of the OCIAA, and a complete set of "En Guardia," a Spanish-language picture magazine about the war that was produced and distributed by the OCIAA. There are also 15 reels of microfilm containing office correspondence: 6 reels of abstracts of incoming correspondence and 9 reels of complete outgoing correspondence. This correspondence may duplicate some of that within the paper files, but it does include additional correspondence as well.

Also found in this subseries are 61 motion picture films produced and distributed under the auspices of the OCIAA during the years 1940-1944. There is a substantial amount of documentation about the films in the papers of this series. These films appear to be NAR's personal copies. In 1942 the CIAA contracted with Walt Disney to produce 18 films, all of which exist at the Archive Center. The Julien Bryan films were produced for a primary and secondary level school audience. The films are in English or Spanish and address health, education, and cultural issues. The films are presented by the CIAA and are live-action in presentation unless otherwise noted.

did.unittitle: Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs (CIAA)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Under Nelson Rockefeller, the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs was created to support various health and social wellness initiatives, as well as to maintain cultural and commercial relations between North and South America. From 1940 to 1946, the CIAA used films and posters to advertise their projects in Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Haiti, Mexico, Peru, Uruguay, and Venezuela.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In 1942, the CIAA contracted Walt Disney Studios to produce 18 films, all of which are available at the RAC. An additional set of films produced by the Julien Bryan Studio created for a primary and secondary level school audience were not commissioned individually by the CIAA, but are included here because of their related content. Many of these films are in Spanish, and some are animated features, or a combination of animation and live-action.

There is a substantial amount of documentation about these films in the Nelson Rockefeller papers. These reels, including the material produced by Walt Disney Productions, are thought to be Nelson Rockefeller's personal copies.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). did.unittitle: Dumbarton Oaks Amendments, Latin American Proposals

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This private international organization was established in June 1940 to reorganize and revitalize Latin American economies following the loss of European markets. The Commission was largely financed by the U.S. government, and Rockefeller was made chairman as an extension of his duties as Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: President Harry S. Truman appointed Rockefeller to the chairmanship of this board, which was charged with developing a plan for providing foreign technical assistance as part of the President's Point IV program.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: There are three divisions in this subseries: Special Committee on Government Organization (SCOGO) Reorganization Advisory Committee (RAC) President's Advisory Committee on Government Organization (PACGO)

The chronological order of the three committees is as follows: RAC, SCOGO, and then PACGO. When this subseries was processed, SCOGO was processed before RAC. Thus, the order for the subseries became SCOGO, RAC, PACGO.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: President-elect Dwight D. Eisenhower asked Rockefeller to chair a committee to study the executive branch of the federal government and recommend ways to streamline its organization and improve its efficiency and effectiveness. The committee was known progressively by three different names, which are reflected in the three titles in this subseries. As chairman, Rockefeller recommended 13 reorganization plans, 10 of which were approved by Congress. In 1953, Rockefeller also served as chairman of the Special Committee on the Reorganization of the Defense Department. Its recommendations were also accepted and approved. The records of his service in that committee are included in this subseries. The PACGO material also includes published reports and correspondence concerning two earlier government organization studies: the Hoover Commission and the Temple University Survey of Government Organization.

did.unittitle: Department of Health, Education, and Welfare (HEW)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One of the recommendations of the President's Advisory Committee on Government Organization led to the creation of the Department of Health, Education, and Welfare. As Under Secretary, Rockefeller was especially active in the department's legislative program, recommending measures that greatly expanded the coverage of the Social Security program. Included in the bound volumes is Rockefeller's chronological out-going correspondence from his entire tenure in this position.

did.unittitle: Special Assistant to the President for Foreign Affairs (SAP)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As Special Assistant to President Eisenhower, Rockefeller played a key role in the development of the Open Skies policy for checking on global military activities through mutual air reconnaissance. He accompanied the President to the Four Powers Conference in Geneva in 1955. Additionally, please refer to Subseries 9 for declassified files from this time period. (NOTE: Some documents in this subseries bear U.S. government security classifications and therefore remain closed.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The day after his inauguration, President Richard M. Nixon requested that Rockefeller consult with the leaders of the Latin American republics and determine the needs and conditions of those countries. In four separate trips during 1969, Rockefeller and a team of advisors visited 20 South American, Central American, and Caribbean republics. His advisors represented the fields of labor, cultural affairs, urban affairs, women's affairs, youth, media, finance and economics, and private enterprise. While Mr. Rockefeller met with the head of state and foreign minister of each country, the advisors met with public and private representatives of their respective fields. This subseries includes briefing books on each country provided by the U.S. Department of State, correspondence with Latin American and U.S. ambassadors, country reports prepared by the advisors, Rockefeller's notes from his meetings with heads of state, and drafts of the final report to Congress and President Nixon. (Note: Some documents in this subseries bear U.S. government security classifications and therefore remain closed.)

Special Assistant to the President Declassified Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: During 1954 and 1955, Nelson Rockefeller served as Special Assistant to President Eisenhower, as documented in Subseries 7. This subseries contains pages declassified in 2006 that had been separated previously from the folders of the same titles in Subseries 7.

NOTE: A single folder in this subseries (S1) originates from Rockefeller's appointment in 1969 to lead President Nixon's Mission to Latin America (Subseries 8). Some related documents in this subseries continue to bear U.S. government security classifications and therefore remain closed.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Subseries 9 of this series contains documents that were declassified by the U.S. government during a review by government officials at the Archive Center from 2003 to 2006. Any document that remains classified since the review has been removed from its folder and replaced with a separation sheet to note its original and current locations. Therefore, all materials in the open folders are now declassified, whether or not the classification stamps on them indicate otherwise. Almost all of the declassified documents prominently display a federal agency's declassification stamp and date.
